title: 111_hr6565
content: The Act is titled the "Global Water Access and Equity Act" and establishes an International Water Issues Diplomatic Coordinator. The State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 is amended to establish a Coordinator of United States Government Diplomatic Initiatives for Safe Water and Sanitation Globally within the Department of State. The Coordinator will report directly to the Secretary of State and perform specified duties. The Coordinator of United States Government Diplomatic Initiatives for Safe Water and Sanitation Globally will perform duties and exercise powers prescribed by the Secretary of State. Specific duties include advising the Secretary of State on efforts to ensure developing countries have access to safe water and sanitation, and monitoring US diplomatic policy. The Coordinator of United States Government Diplomatic Initiatives for Safe Water and Sanitation Globally will advise the Secretary of State on efforts to ensure developing countries have access to safe water and sanitation, in line with the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005. Safe water is defined as water for drinking, household use, and crop irrigation. SEC. 11. BUREAU FOR GLOBAL WATER AID. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 is amended to include a new section establishing a Bureau for Global Water Aid. The Bureau for Global Water Aid is established within the United States Agency for International Development, headed by an Assistant Administrator appointed by the President. The Assistant Administrator is responsible for overseeing US Government activities to provide safe water and sanitation to developing countries. The Bureau for Global Water Aid is staffed as necessary by the Assistant Administrator. Amendments under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 include defining "safe water" and specifying the role of the Assistant Administrator for Global Water Aid. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to redesignate a section and make conforming amendments related to the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005. Additionally, the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 is amended in section 104(c)(9). The Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 is amended to define "safe water" and clarify responsibilities under the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005. The Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 is amended to define "safe water" as water for drinking, household use, and crop irrigation. Additionally, responsibilities under the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 are clarified. The Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 is amended to define "safe water" as water for drinking, household use, and crop irrigation. Responsibilities under the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 are clarified by amending sections related to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development and the Committee on Foreign Affairs. The Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 is amended to define "safe water" and clarify responsibilities under the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005. U.S.C. 2152h note is further amended by redesignating sections. SEC. 12. DIVISION OF RESPONSIBILITY. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development coordinates with the Secretary of State to ensure safe water and sanitation activities align with U.S. diplomatic policy. The Secretary of State prioritizes these activities in diplomatic policy. Any reference to the Secretary of State includes the Coordinator of U.S. Government Diplomatic Initiatives for Safe Water and Sanitation. Initiatives to provide safe water and sanitation globally are established by the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956. Any reference to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development is deemed to be a reference to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, acting through the Assistant Administrator for Global Water Aid. The Sense of Congress is to promote efficient water use in developing countries and develop reliable water supplies. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 to carry out the Act and its amendments. Amounts appropriated shall be in addition to other available funds and remain available until expended.
